item.title: Homework 8, research on application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Find in the web what are the distributions that you just simulated.

item.title: Homework 8, application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Consider R (radius), A(angle) uniform rv's and use them as random polar coordinates on a plane. Determine the empirical distribution of the corresponding Cartesian coordinates (X,Y).
  • Search for the methods to generate Normal rv's X from uniform rv's, and simulate the following distribution: X, X², X/Y², X²/Y², X/Y.

item.title: Homework 7, application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Consider a general scheme and the simulation of previous homework and simulate the distribution of p = SUM(xi) , where xi are Bernoulli(lambda/n), with success probability lambda/n, where lambda is a user constant ("arrival rate"),
  • Also plot the distribution of the "interarrival times",
  • Finally, search on the web to understand what you have actually simulated.

item.title: Homework 7, research
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Try to understand the general idea of the Lebesgue-Stieltjes integral and why it is useful concept and notation in Theory of Probability,
  • Explain in your own words the "Law of large numbers" and sketch a simple proof (Markov inequality, Čebyšëv inequality, ... ).

item.title: Homework 6, application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Take any population and any variable X and draw m (large) samples of size n (as you like) and represent the following 2 distributions : Distribution of the Mean and Distribution of the Variance,
  • finally, for each distribution compute mean and variance and compare with the corrisponding values in the population.

item.title: Homework 6, research
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Try to explain in your own words, the concept of population and sampling distribution,
  • show the expected value and variance of the sampling mean and take a look at the same sampling variance.

item.title: Homework 5, research
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Explain all possible derivation of the arithmetic mean and in general of the other common types of averages,
  • illustrate the difference between "mathematical convergence" and "convergence" in probability,
  • illustrate the differences between Descriptive Statistics and Inferential Statistics and the role of probability and probability distributions.

item.title: Homework 5, application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Given an arbitrary rectangle and a distribution, create the corresponding histogram or column chart, with both vertical and horizontal orientation,
  • given a rectangle, enable its movement/resize/zoom using a mouse (this will be the resizable where we will draw alll future charts).

item.title: Homework 4, application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Generate a m sequences of n trials distributed according a Binomial with success probability p and represent the following quantities: absolute frequency of success, relative frequency of success, "normalized" relative frequency of success,
  • in the same chart, add also a vertical histogram representing the distribution of the above 3 types of frequencies on the last trial.

item.title: Homework 4, research
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Illustrate the parallel between the properties of the relative frequency and the axioms for probability,
  • discuss some concrete examples of Measure Space (omega,epsilon,P),
  • illustrate how Measure Theory provides the mathematical foundation for Probability.

item.title: Homework 4, research on application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Give a simple introduction to graphics in the .NET environment. How to create a bitmap and a chart on it,
  • explain in simple terms how to get device coordinates from world coordinates.

item.title: Homework 3, research on application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • A survey on online algorithms (Welford),
  • in particular, Knuth recursion for the computation of the arithmetic mean (average).

item.title: Homework 3, application
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Create a distribution from the data obtained by the program WireShark by reading the CSV file generated by the program.

item.title: Homework 3, research
item.description:
Assignment:

  • Illustrate the concept of conditional, joint, marginal (relative) frequency using a simple bivariate distribution,
  • illustrate the concept of statistical independence and the resulting mathematical relationships between the above frequencies.

item.title: Homework 2, research on application

  • CSV protocol RFC 4180 (definition and rules)

item.title: Homework 2, application

  • make a simple program which uses the objects Random and Timer
  • Make a simple CSV parser
  • Compute an univariate distribution of a variable

item.title: Homework 2, research

  • What is a dataset? From the observation units to the dataset. Attributes and variables,

item.title: About
item.description: Hi there, my name is Andrea, I am a graduate student in computer engineering and now a student in the master’s degree in Cybersecurity at “La Sapienza”. This blog is hosted with GitHub pages and made with Hugo a framework for building websites. Also, if you’re interested about my other past projects, I invite you to check out my Github.
